In the space somehwere between folklore and history, the story of the Taung Child’s discovery is practically apocryphal. The fossil’s discoverer, Dr. Raymond Dart, tells of rummaging through that crate of fossils, discovering the pieces, and then taking time to ruminate upon Darwin’s theory of man’s African origin. Dart’s daydreams were interrupted by his friend, tugging at this sleeve. His friend, a rather frantic, soon-to-be groom, begged Dart to put down the fossils and preform his duties as the best man as the bridal car was quickly approaching. Dart, himself, loved telling that story.
